You will learn simple rigging techniques in Blender to help you with the animation. u003cbr u003e u003cbr u003e u003cspan style= "font-size: large; color: #ff6600; " u003eWhat to do: u003c/span u003e u003cspan style= "font-size: large; color: #ff6600; " u003e u0026nbsp; u003c/span u003e u003c/p u003e n u003cp u003eRead the following to understand the principals of Squash and Stretch: u003c/p u003e n u003cp u003e u003ca href= "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Squash_and_stretch " target= "_new " u003ehttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Squash_and_stretch u003c/a u003e u003c/p u003e n u003cp u003e u0026nbsp; u003c/p u003e n u003cp u003eCreate another bouncing ball scene, this time using physics rather than armatures. u003c/p u003e n u003cp u003eThis scene will incorporate a minimum of three u0026nbsp;balls, each having a different mass and u0026nbsp;plasticity. For example, they may u0026nbsp;react like a playground ball, a bowling ball, a ping pong ball, etc. u003c/p u003e n u003cp u003eEach ball must travel predominantly along a different axis. For example, one ball must move mostly along the X, another along the Y, and the other along the Z. u003c/p u003e n u003cp u003eAdd materials that reflect the color of the axis the ball is traveling. For example, the red ball is moving along the X axis, green along Y, and blue along Z. If you have multiple balls, just color one for each axis. u0026nbsp; u003c/p u003e n u003cp u003eA tutorial is on its way, but a hint to creating balls that react differently is to pay attention to the Friction, Speed, Push/Pull, and Bending u0026nbsp;settings on each ball. Also, the Inner/Outer settings on any other objects with Collision physics. Again, the each ball must bounce at least three times, at least once off a vertical wall or object, and must travel predominantly along separate axis during there movement (i.e. one ball moves along X, another along Y, and the other along Z). The camera(s), therefore, must be in a position(s) to capture the ball movements along all three axis. u003c/p u003e n u003cp u003e u0026nbsp; u003c/p u003e n u003cp u003e u003cstrong u003e u003cspan style= "font-size: medium; " u003ePeer Reviews: u003c/span u003e u003c/strong u003e u003c/p u003e n u003cp u003eAt midnight after submitting your assignment, you will be assigned 2 peer reviews to be completed as homework. post7.title: PBL Project insight questions
post7.content: Do we have final project ideas for a PBL Web Project? . We have already gone through the brainstorming stage and decided on what we are going to be doing for the PBL final project. . Are we considering a project that is best for our educational purpose? . We decided on making a scheduling app that gets data from canvas and uses it to create a schedule. I think this is a good idea with regards to an educational purpose. . Is the project going to hold team members interest for 8 weeks? . All our group members talked about actually using the end result of the project in their daily lives. Considering the convinience of the app we will be designing, I think that we will be motivated enough to get through the 8 weeks. . Does the project have potential for someone to use it beyond the 8 weeks? ie Customer or Sponsor needed? . Since Canvas is used by many institutions and schools, I think that this will definetly be useful for people outside of the 8 week period. . Does the project have potential to be used for Create Performance Task submission? . After reading through the create performance task task, I decided that this would be a good match for it. It fulfills all the requirements. . ... .

post8.title: A gratitude list and some goal setting blog
post8.content: Gratitude list: . I'm grateful for... . Having a house Being able to eat good food Good health Actively trying to improve Being able to do MMA Being understanding Having opportunities . These were a few things that I am grateful for. I will update this list periodically . Goal setting: . A few goals that I have in mind for 2022 are: . Get very good at MMA Expand my understanding of Calculus Maintain a good sleeping schedule Maintain a good physique Stop procrastinating Learning from mistakes . These are some of the goals I have for 2022. . Thank you for reading! . Though this blog post was created for the purpose of a Computer Science extra credit assignment, it taught me to keep track of what I have in life and what my goals are. .

post9.title: What I plan to do for the CB Create Task project

post10.title: AppLab Math quiz blog + CB create task plan
post10.content: My partner, Alan, and I have decided on making a math quiz on applab for the week 4 requirement. We plan on using basic math questions to test out applabs developer tool. We will use the given code blocks and experiment around to find the proper layout for the quiz we want. We plan on giving basic feedback if the user gets a question wrong and uplifting messages when they get it right. We also plan to troll people by telling them that they are guaranteed a 0% on their next math test. It is what it is. Update: While creating I noticed that there were a lot of blocks which I didn't understand. I watched a few youtube videos and implemented some of the blocks to make my app a little bit more interesting. Update 2: After finishing, I realized that onEvent was a very frequently used command. So was the IF controller. I'm exicited to see how we will be developing apps outside of applab. . Purpose: The purpose of this short math quiz is for us, the developers, to have a brief introduction to developing. There is no particular purpose for the user except entertainment. . Data abstraction: I figured out how to get input from a user and how I can implement that into the quiz. . Managing complexity: I organized the code and made it easier to understand by improving the syntax and making notes. . Testing: I self-tested the quiz to eliminate possible errors. I wasn't able to figure out how to eliminate some of the errors, but I was able to eliminate most minor errors. . For the create task project, my idea is making an app that asks a bunch of analysis questions and based on the responses gives you a personality. In short, my idea is making a personality quiz. . Here is the link to my applab quiz: https://studio.code.org/projects/applab/wRy7RcsYiP9vkEcxZ060wxs4Anr52Mdyjh_-OY9OaY4 .

post11.title: Python Lists
post11.content: # variable of type string print("What is the variable name/key?", "value?", "type?", "primitive or collection, why?") name = "John Doe" print("name", name, type(name)) print() # variable of type integer print("What is the variable name/key?", "value?", "type?", "primitive or collection, why?") age = 18 print("age", age, type(age)) print() # variable of type float print("What is the variable name/key?", "value?", "type?", "primitive or collection, why?") score = 90.0 print("score", score, type(score)) print() # variable of type list (many values in one variable) print("What is variable name/key?", "value?", "type?", "primitive or collection?") print("What is different about the list output?") langs = ["Python", "JavaScript", "Java", "Bash"] print("langs", langs, type(langs), "length", len(langs)) print("- langs[3]", langs[3], type(langs[3])) print() # variable of type dictionary (a group of keys and values) print("What is the variable name/key?", "value?", "type?", "primitive or collection, why?") print("What is different about the dictionary output?") person = { "name": name, "age": age, "score": score, "langs": langs } print("person", person, type(person), "length", len(person)) print('- person["name"]', person["name"], type(person["name"])) . What is the variable name/key? value? type? primitive or collection, why? name John Doe <class 'str'> What is the variable name/key? value? type? primitive or collection, why? age 18 <class 'int'> What is the variable name/key? value? type? primitive or collection, why? score 90.0 <class 'float'> What is variable name/key? value? type? primitive or collection? What is different about the list output? langs ['Python', 'JavaScript', 'Java', 'Bash'] <class 'list'> length 4 - langs[3] Bash <class 'str'> What is the variable name/key? value? type? primitive or collection, why? What is different about the dictionary output? person {'name': 'John Doe', 'age': 18, 'score': 90.0, 'langs': ['Python', 'JavaScript', 'Java', 'Bash']} <class 'dict'> length 4 - person["name"] John Doe <class 'str'> . InfoDb = [] # InfoDB is a data structure with expected Keys and Values # Append to List a Dictionary of key/values related to a person and cars InfoDb.append({ "FoodName": "Chocolate Genoise sponge", "Cuisine": "German", "Price": "$5", "Calories": "230", "Ingredients": ["Eggs", "Milk", "Cocoa Powder", "Sugar", "Vanilla Extract", "Flour"] }) # Append to List a 2nd Dictionary of key/values InfoDb.append({ "FoodName": "Chocolate Genoise sponge", "Cuisine": "German", "Price": "$5", "Calories": "230", "Ingredients": ["Eggs", "Milk", "Cocoa Powder", "Sugar", "Vanilla Extract", "Flour"] }) #append to List a 3rd Dictionary of key/values InfoDb.append({ "FoodName": "Chocolate Genoise sponge", "Cuisine": "German", "Price": "$5", "Calories": "230", "Ingredients": ["Eggs", "Milk", "Cocoa Powder", "Sugar", "Vanilla Extract", "Flour"] }) #append to List a 3rd Dictionary of key/values InfoDb.append({ "FoodName": "Chocolate Genoise sponge", "Cuisine": "German", "Price": "$5", "Calories": "230", "Ingredients": ["Eggs", "Milk", "Cocoa Powder", "Sugar", "Vanilla Extract", "Flour"] }) # Print the data structure print(InfoDb) . def question_and_answer(prompt): print("Question: " + prompt) msg = input() print("Answer: " + msg) question_and_answer("Please write your preference below:") . import getpass, sys def question_with_response(prompt): print("Question: " + prompt) msg = input() return msg . # print function: given a dictionary of InfoDb content #d_rec is the dictionary #to access dictionary you use the key values and to access the List you use indexes def print_data(d_rec): print(d_rec["FirstName"], d_rec["LastName"]) # using comma puts space between values print(" t", "Residence:", d_rec["Residence"]) # t is a tab indent print(" t", "Birth Day:", d_rec["DOB"]) print(" t", "Cars: ", end="") # end="" make sure no return occurs print(", ".join(d_rec["Owns_Cars"])) # join allows printing a string list with separator print() # for loop algorithm iterates on length of InfoDb def for_loop(): print("For loop output n") for record in InfoDb: print_data(record) for_loop() .
